sentences.sentence: COVID-19 has exposed and amplified deep global fissures after decades of increasing globalization and heightened multilateral co-operation.Stoked by a rising tide of nationalism in the United States, China and Russia, we are witnessing a breathtaking decline in international co-operation in response to the global pandemic and worldwide recession.

This stands in stark contrast to the global financial crisis of 2008, when the G20 - with U.S. leadership and strong support from China, Europe, Canada and others - saw us through the storm.Post-pandemic, the combination of trade and security concerns with China and the aftermath of COVID-19 are likely to keep the world on a path towards deglobalization and the restructuring of global supply chains.As part of this, supply chains that rely on Chinese manufacturing will disperse across Asia, transnational technology transfers will face heavier scrutiny over security concerns, international student flows will diminish and even the internet will develop walls, particularly between China and the West.

On top of this, geopolitical tensions are likely to rise in the sea lanes and disputed territories of Southeast Asia and along the new silk road, the signature initiative of Chinese President Xi Jinping.While the U.S. is hardly a passive bystander in all of this, it is an increasingly solitary actor, having eschewed its traditional partners, international institutions and postwar alliances under the Trump administration.

And yet, many countries share American concerns about unfair Chinese trade practices, forced technology transfers, human rights infringements and hyper-aggressive diplomacy.It is therefore curious that it so difficult these days for U.S. foreign policy to build bridges, rather than walls, on issues ranging from China, to Russian adventurism, to climate change, to trade rules that are of mutual benefit to the U.S. and its estranged allies.
But this doesn't have to be the case.

Canada and the U.S. have many shared interests, including continental defence, Arctic sovereignty, energy independence and sustainability, environmental stewardship, technological leadership and open international markets.Almost 60 years ago, U.S. President John F. Kennedy told the Canadian Parliament that, "Geography has made us neighbours.
History has made us friends.
Economics has made us partners.
And necessity has made us allies.
Those whom nature hath so joined together, let no man put asunder.
What unites us is far greater than what divides us.
"Today, in this increasingly dangerous and uncertain world, the U.S. and Canada should be seeking to strengthen our bonds, not fray our relationship.
The new United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, the successor to NATFA that took effect on July 1, offered a positive step forward.

Yet, six weeks later, U.S. President Donald Trump slapped tariffs on Canadian aluminum, moving our bilateral relationship many steps backwards - yet again.Undermining an enforceable, rules-based trade system hurts medium-sized open economies like Canada's much more than it does the U.S., China or Russia.

Therefore, Canada has to move beyond virtue signalling and invest more in areas of shared interest, such as increasing our military presence and leadership in the Arctic, which is becoming more of a focal point for China and Russia.Together with our American neighbours, we should also invest in upgrading NORAD's 1980s-era North Warning System to ensure we can detect and deter a new range of possible attacks, including cyberattacks.
As we saw with COVID-19, threats that go unchecked can have disastrous consequences.

We should work together on a common approach to internet protocols, including cybersecurity and privacy, to avoid "splinternets" among Western countries.We also have a shared interest in ensuring that both countries have an adequate supply of critical goods ranging from personal protective equipment to pharmaceutical compounds.

We have a common interest in investing in next-generation North American energy grids and clean energy production, and expanding environmental co-operation beyond the path-breaking Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement, which is nearing its 50th anniversary.Following the U.S. presidential election in November, we need an in-depth reappraisal of the Canada-U.S. relationship to ensure we work together on the many areas that serve our extensive common interests.
But it will take renewed political willingness and creative policy thinking on both sides of our shared border.
As President Kennedy said, "The issues and irritants that inevitably affect all neighbours are small deed in comparison with the issues that we face together.
"National PostKevin Lynch is the former vice-chair of BMO Financial Group and former clerk of the Privy Council.

Paul Deegan is CEO of Deegan Public Strategies and former deputy executive director of the National Economic Council in the Clinton White House.NP View: Friends don't slap tariffs on friends(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/np-view-friends-dont-slap-tariffs-on-friends)Michael Hood: Securing Canadian sovereignty in a post-COVID world(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/michael-hood-securing-canadian-sovereignty-in-a-post-covid-world) !
@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
